messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Chromatic ğ‘˜-Nearest Neighbor Queries

Paper Abstract: Abstract Let Pğ‘ƒP be a set of nğ‘›n colored points. We develop efficient data structures that store Pğ‘ƒP and can answer chromatic kğ‘˜k-nearest neighbor (kğ‘˜k-NN) queries. Such a query consists of a query point qğ‘q and a number kğ‘˜k, and asks for the color that appears most frequently among the kğ‘˜k points in Pğ‘ƒP closest to qğ‘q. Answering such queries efficiently is the key to obtain fast kğ‘˜k-NN classifiers. Our main aim is to obtain query times that are independent of kğ‘˜k while using near-linear space. We show that this is possible using a combination of two data structures. The first data structure allow us to compute a region containing exactly the kğ‘˜k-nearest neighbors of a query point qğ‘q, and the second data structure can then report the most frequent color in such a region. This leads to linear space data structures with query times of Oâ€‹(n1/2â€‹logâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›12ğ‘›O(n^{1/2}\log n) for points in â„1superscriptâ„1\mathbb{R}^{1}, and with query times varying between Oâ€‹(n2/3â€‹log2/3â¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›23superscript23ğ‘›O(n^{2/3}\log^{2/3}n) and Oâ€‹(n5/6â€‹polylogâ¡n)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›56polylogğ‘›O(n^{5/6}\operatorname{polylog}n), depending on the distance measure used, for points in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2}. Since these query times are still fairly large we also consider approximations. If we are allowed to report a color that appears at least (1âˆ’Îµ)â€‹fâˆ—1ğœ€superscriptğ‘“(1-\varepsilon)f^{*} times, where fâˆ—superscriptğ‘“f^{*} is the frequency of the most frequent color, we obtain a query time of Oâ€‹(logâ¡n+logâ¡log11âˆ’Îµâ¡n)ğ‘‚ğ‘›subscript11ğœ€ğ‘›O(\log n+\log\log_{\frac{1}{1-\varepsilon}}n) in â„1superscriptâ„1\mathbb{R}^{1} and expected query times ranging between O~â€‹(n1/2â€‹Îµâˆ’3/2)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›12superscriptğœ€32\tilde{O}(n^{1/2}\varepsilon^{-3/2}) and O~â€‹(n1/2â€‹Îµâˆ’5/2)~ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›12superscriptğœ€52\tilde{O}(n^{1/2}\varepsilon^{-5/2}) in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} using near-linear space (ignoring polylogarithmic factors).

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Vertical decomposition of shallow levels in 3-dimensional arrangements and its applications",
        "On range searching with semialgebraic sets",
        "On range searching with semialgebraic sets. II",
        "Data classification: algorithms and applications",
        "Tight lower bounds for halfspace range searching",
        "Regularity lemmas and combinatorial algorithms",
        "Multidimensional divide-and-conquer",
        "On the complexity of higher order abstract voronoi diagrams",
        "Approximate range mode and range median queries",
        "Optimal partition trees",
        "Speeding up the four russians algorithm by about one more logarithmic factor",
        "Linear-space data structures for range mode query in arrays",
        "Further Results on Colored Range Searching",
        "Cutting hyperplanes for divide-and-conquer",
        "A singly exponential stratification scheme for real semi-algebraic varieties and its applications",
        "New applications of random sampling in computational geometry",
        "Nearest neighbor pattern classification",
        "Ray Shooting, Depth Orders and Hidden Surface Removal, volume 703 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science",
        "Cuttings and applications",
        "The upper envelope of piecewise linear functions: Tight bounds on the number of faces",
        "Simulation of simplicity: a technique to cope with degenerate cases in geometric algorithms",
        "A general approach to removing degeneracies",
        "Boolean matrix multiplication and transitive closure",
        "An algorithm for finding best matches in logarithmic expected time",
        "Approximating the k-level in three-dimensional plane arrangements",
        "A kğ‘˜k-nearest-neighbour classifier for assessing consumer credit risk",
        "Dynamic planar voronoi diagrams for general distance functions and their algorithmic applications",
        "Almost tight upper bounds for vertical decompositions in four dimensions",
        "Range mode and range median queries on lists and trees",
        "An adaptive nearest neighbor classification algorithm for data streams",
        "Two-dimensional voronoi diagrams in the lp-metric",
        "On k-nearest neighbor voronoi diagrams in the plane",
        "Nearly optimal planar k nearest neighbors queries under general distance functions",
        "The k-nearest-neighbor voronoi diagram revisited",
        "Range searching with efficient hierarchical cuttings",
        "Combinatorial optimization with rational objective functions",
        "Applying parallel computation algorithms in the design of serial algorithms",
        "Chromatic nearest neighbor searching: A query sensitive approach",
        "The upper envelope of piecewise linear functions and the boundary of a region enclosed by convex plates: Combinatorial analysis",
        "Planar point location using persistent search trees",
        "Point location",
        "Data structures and network algorithms",
        "New data structures for orthogonal range queries",
        "Geometric consistency theorem for a symbolic perturbation scheme",
        "An improved combinatorial algorithm for boolean matrix multiplication"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Chromatic ğ‘˜-Nearest Neighbor Queries, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
